newsitem.title: UK: Gulf War Syndrome - maybe a pesticide link - Britain.
newsitem.headline: Gulf War Syndrome - maybe a pesticide link - Britain.

text.p: Britain said on Friday that certain pesticides used in the 1991 Gulf War could be linked to veterans' complaints popularly known as Gulf War Syndrome.

"The use of some OPs (organophosphate pesticides) may possibly be a clue to the conditions that some Gulf War veterans have suffered from," said Nicholas Soames, defence minister for the armed forces, in a statement. "It will be investigated fully and with the utmost care."

Soames said that, during a review of operational and environmental conditions during the Gulf War, it became clear that organophosphate pesticides had been used more widely than had previously been believed.

Authority was given to purchase some OPs in the Gulf area, he said in a letter to the chairman of a parliamentary defence committee. While the government knew that one OP, malathion, was used, there was now evidence that three others were used.
"We are conducting urgent investigations into the extent of use of such pesticides and I will write to you once we have a clearer picture on this," he said.
Britain's defence ministry previously said it believed the sometimes crippling ailments described by veterans had been caused by stress.
